title: A Visual Guide to the Aztec Pantheon
introduction: South American and Mesoamerican civilizations have fascinated me since childhood, when I would watch The Mysterious Cities of Gold. This early 1980s Japanese-French anime series featured a solar-powered galleon ship, a golden, mechanical condor, three kids exploring the New World at the beginning of the Spanish Conquest, and a mini documentary at the end of each episode. Who could ask for more? (There was even a sequel in 2012!)

But, despite this enchantment, Quetzalcoatl and Tlaloc were the only gods I could identify, while I could name dozens of Greek, Egyptian or Norse Gods. Only ten years ago, I learned about Aztec codices and a whole world of deities, each taking care of some aspects of human life.

Using these codices, I tried to identify them all, like a Pokemon chaser, despite scattered, partial and sometimes contradictory sources. I finally collected and restored illustrations of more than a hundred gods.

Through these illustrations, I hope to commemorate the complexity of the Aztec Pantheon, make the academic research more accessible, and show how this civilization is still alive in our global culture. With luck, they will also help you see this society with your inner child’s eyes, just like I did all those years ago.

iconography.text: Aztec gods, in iconographic sources, are like paper dolls. Important symbolic accessories are added to their initial form. Even specialists have difficulty identifying gods as these symbols can be emphasized for a particular worship, or switched between deities if they share similar fields of competence. Thus, gods can have multiple disguises, or nahual, and share them with others, like a never-ending stream.
On the restored images below, Tlaltecuhtli and Tezcatlipoca are represented with their typical attributes.

tezca-steps.text: Tezcatlipoca rules night, death, discord, conflict, temptation, change and destruction.

tezca-steps.title: colors
tezca-steps.text: He is usually represented with black and red as predominant colors.

tezca-steps.title: face
tezca-steps.text: Yellow and black stripes are used for the face.

tezca-steps.title: spear
tezca-steps.text: He carries a spear to judge humans.

tezca-steps.title: mirror
tezca-steps.text: His obsidian mirror is used for divination.

tezca-steps.title: headdress
tezca-steps.text: The elaborate headdress represents swirling smoke that emanates from his mirror.

tezca-steps.title: foot
tezca-steps.text: Tezcatlipoca’s foot was bitten off by Tlaltecuhtli in a battle. It is sometimes replaced by smoke, a scroll or a snake.

tezca-steps.title: skin
tezca-steps.text: The jaguar skin is the main nahual of Tezcatlipoca.

tezca-steps.title: pectoral
tezca-steps.text: Circular pectoral (anahuatl) over the chest, made up of a white shell ring tied on by a red leather strap.

tezca-steps.title: nose plug
tezca-steps.text: The nose plug made of jade is a religious and/or a social ranking ornament.

tezca-steps.title: ezpitzal
tezca-steps.text: Absent symbol in this illustration: the ezpitzal (gust of blood) symbolizing anger, rage or madness.

source_tlalte_label: Colorized detail from a stone sculpture exhibited at the Templo Mayor museum

tlalte-steps.text: Tlaltecuhtli is a sea monster creature, considered to be the source of all living things. It has to be kept appeased by blood sacrifices, as it swallows the sun each night.

tlalte-steps.title: claws
tlalte-steps.text: Clawed hands and feet are a symbol of ferocity and blood thirst for sacrifice.

tlalte-steps.title: hair
tlalte-steps.text: Curly hair is a symbol of grass (malinali).

tlalte-steps.title: mouth
tlalte-steps.text: Its wide open mouth swallows the sun at the end of each day.

tlalte-steps.title: extramouths
tlalte-steps.text: Extra mouths at the joints, and skull ornaments, emphasize the all consuming aspect of death.

tlalte-steps.title: crouch
tlalte-steps.text: The crouching position can be a symbol of the birthing process and fertility.

library: Other common attributes are feathers and jade for nobility and power; a walking stick suggests a merchant; skulls and bones evoke the underworld; claws or fangs allude to a sacrificial dimension, etc.
The Gods illustrated below are imaginary. These made-up illustrations show how symbols and attributes in real Aztec iconography were composed to depict a God’s domain, abilities and needs.
pantheon_intro: These symbols can be found in real Aztec iconography, like in the 130 restored illustrations below.
But Aztec Gods are rarely associated with a single domain like death or fertility. On the contrary, apparently contradictory domains of human life are often embodied by the same deity.

pantheon.text: I organized the Gods of this pantheon according to whether they are associated with death or life, and whether their domain is more spiritual or material.
Death relates to the Underworld, war, and destruction in general.
Fertility, birth, food or creation belong to life.
Gods related to nature, lust, excess or celestial bodies have a more spiritual expansion.
Whereas Gods related to trade, food or water have a more material expansion.
But Aztec Gods rarely fit in a single category, and most are both creative and destructive, spiritual and material, especially major Gods.
Tlaltecuhtli, for instance, destroys the sun every day, but is also the source of all living things.
Explore the illustrations and find out how visual attributes depicts a God’s domain.
You can start with Ometeotl, often deemed as the primordial God, as he is the cosmic energy that gives life to everything.

main_gods.name: Ometeotl
main_gods.title: The matrix of all things
main_gods.minibio: Androgynous entity, Ometeotl is responsible for the creation of the gods and the world, on the back of Cipactli, but stays distant from mankind.

sources_group.title: Reshaping the world: debates on Mesoamerican cosmologies
sources_group.author: Ana Maria Diaz Alvarez

sources_group.title: Ometeotl and the Emergence of the Male-Female Polarity in Aztec Cosmogony
sources_group.author: Sylvie Peperstraete

sources_group.title: Ometeotl, the God that Didn’t Exist

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: The only symbol of truth and permanence for Aztecs is Ometeotl, the cosmic energy which gives life to everything, and structures it, like a fabric upon which gods and humans weave their history. Ometeotl doesn’t seem to be worshiped, besides mentions by some poets. However, he’s the core of the Aztec worldview. Like the cell’s mitosis, Ometeotl divides himself into Ometecuhtli (male) and Omecihuatl (female), then into the four creation gods. So every Aztec god is a specific disguise or embodiment of Ometeotl.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: This deity is still celebrated annually in Morelos at the Ometeotl festival, which showcases the diversity of Mexican culture. But Ometeotl’s legacy can also be seen in the work of French philosopher and sociologist Edgar Morin who popularized the concept of complex systems. The Aztec’s pantheon is indeed a perfect example of it, where all the parts interact with each other in various ways, culminating in a higher order.

main_gods.name: Huitzilopochtli
main_gods.title: The emperor god
main_gods.minibio: God of war, thunderstorms, fire and sun. He's the original deity of the nomadic tribe of Mexica, also known as Aztecs. He was a warrior who needed blood to win his battle against darkness.

sources_group.title: Incarnations of the Aztec Supernatural: The Image of Huitzilopochtli in Mexico and Europe
sources_group.author: Elizabeth H. Boone

sources_group.title: Huitzilopochtli: The History of the Aztec God of War and Human Sacrifice
sources_group.author: Ernesto Novato

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Huitzilopochtli is the protector of Aztec people through their journey from the mythic city of Aztlan (potentially the north of Mexico) to Texcoco Lake, where they built Tenochtitlan. Struggling to feed the fifth sun (Tonatiuh) and thus allowing the whole world to exist, Aztecs helped him thanks to wars, conquests and captives. While their blood is spilled to the ground to feed the earth, their heart is offered to the sun. Once again, death brings life.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: The presence of Huitzilopochtli is still obvious today. Look no further than Mexico’s flag. At the center of it, an eagle eats a snake on a cactus. The same that Mexica saw upon their arrival at Texcoco. But, mainly, Huitzilopochtli's shadow still lies over the political landscape. The Empire his followers built (one which roughly restructured the countryside and created a sense of unity, despite the variety of local cultures) reshaped Mexican history well into the present.

main_gods.name: Quetzalcoatl
main_gods.title: The civilizing god
main_gods.minibio: One of the main divinities worshiped in Mesoamerica. He's the god of agriculture, arts, love science and wind. Exiled by his brother Tezcatlipoca, his expected return has been seen, at first, as the arrival of Hernan Cortez in 1519.

sources_group.title: Quetzalcoatl, in myth, archeology, and art
sources_group.author: Demetrio Sodi, José López Portillo and Fernando Díaz Infante

sources_group.title: The myth of Quetzalcoatl
sources_group.author: Enrique Florescano

sources_group.title: The Myth of Quetzalcoatl: Religion, Rulership, and History in the Nahua World
sources_group.author: Alfredo López Austin

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Quiche, Mayan or Toltecs: The feathered serpent figure has been revered for centuries in Mesoamerica. Although he’s a major fertility god for Aztecs, he also birthed a sweeter life for humans by giving them agriculture, science, arts, game, medicine and drugs, and especially love.

All those gifts remain in Mexican culture, thanks to historical and archeological work, but the most vivacious one remains the Náhuatl language. Spoken since the 7th century, today it’s the second most common language in the country, with around 2M speakers, mostly in rural areas.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: Like Breton’s dialect in France, contemporary Náhuatl is not the same as the original, as it has been Latinized and standardized since the Spanish Conquest, not to mention the fragmentation of Náhuatl into a multitude of local variations, and the urban migration, which weakens its transmission. Local dialects became, in the early 1990s, a strong symbol for the recognition of indigenous rights. And, finally, in 2003, they were recognized as co-official national languages by the government.

main_gods.name: Tezcatlipoca
main_gods.title: The trickster
main_gods.minibio: Omnipotent god of rulers, sorcerers or warriors, he rules night, death, discord, conflict, temptation, change and destruction. Symbolized by the jaguar, he's a rival of Quetzalcoatl and one of the most complex Aztec gods.

sources_group.title: Nahualism
sources_group.author: Roberto Martinez Gonzalez

sources_group.title: Tezcatlipoca: trickster and supreme deity
sources_group.author: Elizabeth Baquedano

sources_group.title: A Guide to Mexican Witchcraft
sources_group.author: William Madsen, Claudia Madsen Mariana Yampolsky

sources_group.title: Shamanism in Mexico
sources_group.author: William Madsen

sources_group.title: Symbolizing Tezcatlipoca
sources_group.author: Nicholas J. Saunders and Elizabeth Baquedano

sources_group.title: Le nahualli : homme-dieu et double animal au Mexique
sources_group.author: Roberto Martinez Gonzalez

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Protector of young warriors, rulers and even slaves, he’s also a powerful sorcerer. Both a destructive and creative god, his shapeshifting allows him to trick people. And his omniscience permits him to reward or punish them, depending on his mood.

Nahual (or nagual), the ability to connect with a spirit animal, was strong in Aztec culture, as every man was born under one, which brought specific traits of character or a particular destiny. It was popularized by the anthropologist Carlos Casteneda in the 1960’s and spread through New Age movements.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: Despite witch hunts during the Spanish Conquest, magic has survived into the present, with brujos/brujas or curanderos/curanderas, especially in the south of Mexico Valley, Tuxtla (Chiapas) or in Catemaco, a village near Vera Cruz, where politicians still come to seek mystical help before elections.

main_gods.name: Xipe Totec
main_gods.title: A renewal figure
main_gods.minibio: Fierce god of agriculture, fertility, seasons and renewal, he was also a protector of gold workers, jewelers and warriors. He flayed himself to give humanity food, and was shown as wearing a flayed human skin.

sources_group.title: The Flayed God and His Rattle-Stick: A Shamanic Element in Pre-Hispanic Mesoamerican Religion
sources_group.author: Franke J. Neumann

sources_group.title: Flayed Lord Xipe Totec: An Ancient God Without Skin Dug Up In 2020
sources_group.author: Brian Gilmore

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Xipe Totec is an old god, whose origin dates back as far as Olmec civilization, and merges very well with the two sides of Aztecs civilisation: the agrarian native tribes in the Valley of Mexico and the warrior-nomadic trait of the northern tribes which arrived in the 11th century. Like the kernel of the maize, Xipe Totec removed his own skin to provide Aztec people food and, by giving their blood during gladiatorial sacrifices, warriors thus ensured the survival of the whole community.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: Xipe Totec would have been an excellent ship’s figurehead for the Zapatista delegation who set sail in May 2021 for Europe, as he symbolizes the “inverted colonization” of Mexican food in Western civilizations. Without him, there would be no tomato (“tomate” in nahuatl) sauce in Italy, no fried potatoes (“camohtli”) in France or Belgium, or chewing gum (“chicle”), chocolate (“xocoatl”) and popcorn (“momochitl”) invading movie theaters.

main_gods.name: Xiuhtecuhtli
main_gods.title: The center of the universe
main_gods.minibio: God of fire and time, protector of kings, warriors and pochtecas. One of the oldest cult in Aztec mythology. He's also deeply connected with birth.

sources_group.title: Le vieux dieu : Vies et morts d'une divinité ignée sur les Hauts Plateaux mexicains
sources_group.author: Claire Billard

sources_group.title: Ciclos de tiempo y significado en los libros mexicanos del destino
sources_group.author: Elizabeth Hill Boone

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Domestic fire is one of the first characteristics of human civilization and its ability to transform nature. Revered since the preclassical period (1500 BC – 100 CE) as Huehueteotl (“Old god”), Xiuhtecuhtli is the protector of the Aztec calpulli (kind of like a European house which administered an urban or rural territory) and thus seen as the center of the universe, appearing both at the intersection of the cardinal points and vertical levels of the outerworld.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: Every 52 years, the two Aztec calendars, which were inspired by the Mayan system, converged and a ceremony to renew the divine fire would take place. It was a key moment, fueled with apprehension. Those calendars were believed to merge again in 2012 and for some who hoped for radical changes to society after a major event, this year was seen as a potential date for the end of the world. But there was a basic misconception of Mesoamerican cycles, where time was seen more like a circle, with continual renewal.

main_gods.name: Tlaloc
main_gods.title: The master of water
main_gods.minibio: Main aztec god, with Huitzilopochtli, who controls rain, hurricanes, fertility and lightning. He's also associated with springs, mountains and caves. Babies were drowned to give him power.

sources_group.title: The rules of construction of an Aztec deity Chalchiuhtlicue, the goddess of water
sources_group.author: Danièle Dehouve

sources_group.title: Tlaloc: The History of the Aztec God of Rain and Giver of Life
sources_group.author: Ernesto Novato

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Tlaloc and Huitzilopochtli overlooked the Aztec people from the top of Templo Mayor in Tenochtitlan. The rain god Tlaloc was the symbol of the agrarian and sedentary people of the Valley of Mexico, who merged with the nomadic tribes to form the Aztec civilization. Built on Texcoco lake and prone to droughts and floods, the agricultural system was heavily dependent on water, thus many sacrifices were made to appease Tlaloc.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: The Valley of Mexico has been strongly transformed since, and most of the lakes have disappeared due to urbanization and modification of agricultural techniques. The Aztecs’ channeling of water through dams, aqueducts and chinampas, has still survived in some places, like Xochimilco. But many areas have suffered these past years from chronic water shortages.

main_gods.name: Mictlantecuhtli
main_gods.title: The ruler of the underworld
main_gods.minibio: God of death and lord of Mictlan, the main Aztec underworld. Living in complete darkness, he guards the bones of dead people but also babies before their birth.

sources_group.title: El Mictlan Entre Los Mexica
sources_group.author: Ignacio de la Garza Galvez

sources_group.title: Llewellyn's Little Book of the Day of the Dead
sources_group.author: Jaime Gironés

sources_group.title: Iconography in Mexico's Day of the Dead: Origins and Meaning
sources_group.author: Stanley Brandes

sources_group.title: The Saint Death and the syncretism in the work of Homero Aridjis
sources_group.author: Weselina Gacinska

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Unlike Christian beliefs, Aztec afterlife doesn’t depend on the way you lived but on the way you died. Drown, you went to Tlaloc’s country, died in childbirth, you joined the Cihuateteo and, supreme honor, sacrificial victims and warriors would stay with Tonatiuh. But those who died of natural causes had to go through the land of Mictlan and pass a series of trials, in order to gradually give up their soul, their spirit and their vitality.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: Death, especially symbolized by skulls, skeletons or marigolds, still has a major place in Mexican folklore, thanks to the 19th cartoonist José Guadalupe Posada, and more importantly, in our collective psyche, to the Dia de los Muertos, which combines both Christians and Aztec elements. And the gory, spooky and violent iconography of death deities are still a great inspiration for the cholo’s subculture, from Cypress Hill to Prayers and his “cholo goth,” or death metal bands.

main_gods.name: Tlaltecuhtli
main_gods.title: The benevolent and monstrous earth
main_gods.minibio: Sea monster creature, considered as the source of all living things. It has to be kept benevolent by blood sacrifices, as it swallows the sun each night.

sources_group.title: Coatlicue o la degollación de la madre
sources_group.author: Jean-Claude Delhalle & Albert Luykx

sources_group.title: Great Goddesses of the Aztecs: Their Meaning and Functions
sources_group.author: Aleksandar Boskovic

sources_group.title: Aspects of Death symbolism in aztec Tlaltecuhtli
sources_group.author: Elisabeth Baquedano

sources_group.title: Ensayo pre iconográfico sobre Tlaltecuhtli, diosa de la Tierra
sources_group.author: Carmen Aguilera

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: In the Aztec cosmogony, or worldview, the universe was, at first, a gigantic reptilian monster and called, according to different sources, Cipactli or Tlaltecuhtli. Its body, dismembered by Quetzalcoatl and Tezcatlipoca, was then used to create the earth. There are still raging debates on its identity (male or female) but Tlaltecuhtli, like Tezcatlipoca, is both a matrix, a creator of life, and a destructor, devouring the sun at the end of each day.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: The nurturing aspect of earth has merged, since 1531, into the cult of the Virgin of Guadalupe, whose followers are still widespread in Mexico. But some believe that the monstrous and destructive aspects of Tlaltecuhtli still lay in the ground of Mexico, due to the collective apprehension of disastrous earthquakes, like the notorious one in 1985, which left 10,000 dead and 30,000 wounded.

main_gods.name: Yacatecuhtli
main_gods.title: The protector of traders
main_gods.minibio: God of merchants and travelers, especially pochtecas. Depicted as a man with a long nose and a stick, he opens the way for Gods to travel to the mortal world and also clears a path for the imperial armies.

sources_group.title: Espace, guerre et prospérité dans l'ancien Mexique central : les dieux des marchands à l'époque postclassique
sources_group.author: Oliver Guilhem

sources_group.title: Mexican Drug Cartel Influence in Government, Society, and Culture
sources_group.author: Jacob JiHyong Kim

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: War and trade were the main tools of Aztec imperialism, which explains the strong connection between Yacatecuhtli, the god of merchants, and Huitzilopochtli, the god of war. Military trained and used as a vanguard (or as an excuse for provoking a war with rivals when they were attacked), the long distance traders known as pochtecas lived in a closed society, with their own jurisdiction and religious ceremonies, kind of like the European guilds.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: There’s no direct cult to Yacatecuhtli, but Mexican narco dealers can be seen as the legitimate heirs of pochtecas: by bringing luxury products to upper classes and using violence in order to conquer new territories, they share a similar relation of rivalty and proximity with the new nobility of politics, media and economy.

main_gods.name: Mixcoatl
main_gods.title: The indigenous god
main_gods.minibio: Chichimec and Otomi god of hunting, war, fire, sky and the Milky Way. Depending on the sources, he could be the father of Huitzilopochtli and Quetzalcoatl or a new form of Tezcatlipoca.

sources_group.title: Iconografía de una imagen de Iztac Mixcóatl, una imagen en el Códice Telleriano-Remensis
sources_group.author: Carmen Aguilera

sources_group.title: Mixcoatl: Aztec God of the Hunt
sources_group.author: Jimmy Joe

sources_group.title: The Invisible War: Indigenous Devotions, Discipline, and Dissent in Colonial Mexico
sources_group.author: David Tavarez

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Mixcoatl is a good example of the complexity and confusions surrounding the Aztec pantheon. Worshipped by Toltecs (around 1000 AD), both as a god and historical figure, and then by the Otomis or Chichimecs people before the arrival of Aztecs, he shared many common attributes with Huitzilopochtli, especially war. This is potentially the consequence of Aztec expansion, which, like the Roman Empire, assimilated or merged several local gods to create a sense of unity.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: The predominance of Aztec civilization obliterated, in our collective psyche, a major fact of Mesoamerican history: the diversity of ethnics groups which lived before, beside, among or even after Aztecs. The question of indigenous rights is still one of the main questions in Mexican politics. And language, a symbol of their particularisms, has been used since as an instrument of political combat.

main_gods.name: Xochiquetzal
main_gods.title: The lady of impermanence
main_gods.minibio: Goddess of female sexuality, prostitutes, homosexuals, young mothers, flowers, pleasure and craft (embroiders, weavers, silversmiths and sculptors).

sources_group.title: Xochipilli “Le prince des fleurs”. Etude iconographique et textuelle d’une divinité aztèque
sources_group.author: Ingrid Lizbeth & Bernal Martinez

sources_group.title: Aztec Art
sources_group.author: Manuel Aguilar-Moreno

sources_group.title: Xochihuah and Queer Aztecs
sources_group.author: David Bowles

sources_group.title: Xochipilli and homosexuality
sources_group.author: MasaAmericana website

sources_group.title: Gender and Aztec Life Cycles
sources_group.author: Caroline Dodds Pennock

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Higher pleasures, such as arts and crafts or love, were under the protection of Quetzalcoatl, but also an intriguing and gender-fluid couple: Xochiquetzal and Xochipilli. Whereas order and stability were major virtues for Aztecs, they expressed the beauty of impermanence, always at the edge between spiritual ecstasy and futility or excess, like their symbol: flower.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: Aztecs arts have survived through their architecture, codices, music, ritual dances, and especially their poetry, thanks to the richness of Náhuatl language, or the famous paintings of Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera, or even Keith Haring. Aztec and other Amerindian civilisations are also extremely interesting for LGBTQ+ studies (even if our present attitudes toward gender and sexuality can’t be so easily applied to older societies).

Strict Aztecs laws forbid homosexuality but, despite the biased documents we have, “outcasts” had a kind of acceptance and even a religious role, including gender fluid gods, like Centeotl, gender bending priests during ceremonies and prostitutes (ahuianime) who openly accompanied warriors during their campaigns.

main_gods.name: Mayahuel
main_gods.title: Goddess of pulque
main_gods.minibio: Goddess of the maguay plant and all its by-products, especially pulque. Said to have 400 breasts to nurture her children, she gave love to mankind with her romance with Quetzalcoatl.

sources_group.title: The Children of Mayahuel: Agaves, Human Cultures, and Desert Landscapes in Northern Mexico
sources_group.author: Cynthia Radding

sources_group.title: Mayáhuel: Mesoamerican deities of the maguey, as depicted in the C​odex Borgia
sources_group.author: Richard Guzman

sources_group.author: Zoe Saadia

sources_group.title: The Story of pulque
sources_group.author: Deborah Toner

content.subtitle: Symbolism
subcontent: Pulque (a mild alcoholic beverage made from maguey) is quite a paradoxical element of Aztec culture. Whereas their pantheon counted hundreds of gods related to it, all children of Mayahuel, it was restricted to very few humans (warriors, sacrificial victims, priests and nobles for celebrations or older people and pregnant women) and public drunkenness was severely punished.

content.subtitle: Legacy
subcontent: Maguey plantations brought wealth to powerful families in Mexico during the 19th century, but pulque represents only 10% of the alcoholic beverages consumed in Mexico. However, a modern version of it, thanks to the European distillation technique, became very popular worldwide: tequila. Additionally, maguey, with its low water consumption, is actually a point of interest for agronomists and could help to solve some water problems in Mexico.

codices: Until its rise as an academic field that strives for accuracy, history has been, by definition, written from a single point of view. Concerning our subject, we stumble upon a major difficulty: the Aztecs destroyed materials created by their rivals in order to justify the dominance of their empire. Furthermore, Spanish conquerors and Christian missionaries brought about an even bigger annihilation, toppling Aztec society and rewriting their works.

Fortunately, some of these missionaries tried to collect as much information as they could, especially pioneer of anthropology Bernardino de Sahagún, while others, like Bartolomé de Las Casas, fought for indigenous rights. Their work is still precious to historians.
cta_wip: We have, so far, in our database around 130 gods. And another batch is in the “work in progress” phase, as we still lack information, iconographic resources or simply the time to render them in graphic vector.

We hope to improve and expand it in the future so, if you’re interested in this project, you can contact me (uguengwendal@gmail.com) for corrections in written or iconographic resources. Thank you in advance for your assistance!
cta_mentions: A special thanks to Sylvie Peperstraete, Fiona Pugliese, Ingrid Bernal, Elizabeth Baquedano, Florian Melki, Patrick Lesbre and Ian Mursell for their help and advice during my research.
cta_websites: Mexicolore, a wonderful and rich website for the general public about ancient cultures in Mexico.
MayaIncaAztec, an educational website about indigenous societies in America, where I published my first restorations.
My Corazon Mexica on Etsy and Facebook for their incredible drawings and costumes inspired by aztec mythology.
